1. Build design systems

Building scalable design systems from the ground up is one of my favourites tasks, for example, the work I did for Hellocar. This is valuable to business and the product because you start with the bare building blocks of a product and you scale that building into an experience making it into a system that develops as the product iterates.

2. Multi-disciplined team

The success or the failure of a product never comes down to if you have the best designer or best developer. What it comes down to is how the team works together and delivers the product and this was true with the team in LateRooms. Also, I am not a big fan of waterfalls üöø ‚òπÔ∏è

2. Experiments and Validation

Getting something in front of users helps to validate ideas quickly and cheaply is vital for successful product development, but I also believe you should be bold and challenging to the users. A good example is a work I did for Cambridge Audio.
